title: Before 1 April 2017, will any NATO member other than Turkey announce the establishment of a no-fly zone over any part of Syria?
preds: I doubt anything will happen in terms of NATO Syrian policy until the peace talks in Kazakhstan are commenced.
They've got a few hours left...
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

FT, March 22, 'Israeli air raids in Syria raise fears of wider conflict': https://www.ft.com/content/e5625674-0ee6-11e7-b030-768954394623
Clip from article:
"For the fourth time in the past week, Israeli aircraft have carried out pre-dawn strikes in Syria. This time, rebels say, they hit regime army posts near Damascus.
Among the targets reportedly hit on Wednesday were radar systems, the kind of advanced military equipment Israel’s government says it is determined to keep Hizbollah — allied with Syria’s government and its arch-enemy Iran — from acquiring."
With so little time left for this prediction, and NATO more worried about the USA's continued involvement, there will be little focus on Syria for the moment.

Just in, from a share:
AA.com, March 17, 'Israeli warplanes strike targets in Syria': http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/israeli-warplanes-strike-targets-in-syria/773658
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Too many political issue in EU.
Plans are in process. Not in execution.
Lima Charlie, February 18, 'Syria: Russian Air Force pounds Deraa': http://www.limacharlienews.com/mena/syria-russian-airforce-pounds-daraa/
I'm saying zero because the US isn't going to impose one now and none of the other (non-Turkish) NATO members have the, um, chutzpah to act unilaterally in Syria and risk a conflict with Russia.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
Errant Russian Strike Kills Turkish Soldiers in Syria
Erdogan, Trump agree joint action against Islamic State in Syria: Turkish sources
Physical impossibility. This talk by Erdogan, and earlier by Hillary, has just been theatrics.
U.S.-backed Syrian force in new phase of Raqqa assault
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Re-affirming my forecast based on Erdogan's latest flip-flopping ramblings and NATO position that Turkey must respect the peace treaty.

Russia block in the UN Security Council, so it's hard to see this happening other than as an agreement between US and Russia, or if some dramatic turn of events should happen that will cause full conflict between the two countries
Timeframe makes this very unlikely in my view.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Huff-Po, January 28, 'Donald Trump Withdraws Proposal To Create Safe Zones In Syria - The controversial policy would pose a number of logistical and political problems': http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trump-syria-safe-zones_us_5889175ae4b0024605fd95fb
Trumps hopes for Syria safe zones may force decision on Assad
Small update because of Trump's comment on 'safe zones'. But a safe zone is not a no-fly zone, announcing is not establishing and 1 April 2017 is getting close.
initial forecast on this question... entering the fray against my better judgment...
Well, I went from 2% to 0%, great leap, decisive dive and courageous forecast!
Insitituting a no fly zone of Syria would not be in the interests of the US as it would take away from the US ability to work with Russia against ISIS
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Congresswoman Gabbard makes unannounced trip to Syria 
In the meeting with Trump, she warned him about escalating the civil war in Syria by establishing a no-fly zone to protect civilians from the bombing. She has said she believes that creating such a safe zone off limits to military aircraft could bring the U.S. into direct conflict with Russia and result in nuclear war.
https://www.salon.com/2017/01/18/congresswoman-gabbard-makes-unannounced-trip-to-syria/
Very, very low because of the conflicts that would occur with Syria's supporters.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

The Independent, January 12, 'Russia sends 12 more warplanes to Syria despite announcing military withdrawal - Moscow reportedly sends a dozen Su-25 fighter planes to aid ally Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, days after Russian military said it would decrease its deployment': http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-war-latest-russia-sends-12-more-warplanes-to-syria-despite-announcing-military-withdrawal-a7524351.html
Clips from article:
"However, satellite images captured from the Mediterranean and analysed by security sources show that Russia has moved more equipment -  including a dozen Su-25 fighter planes - to the regime-controlled city of Latakia since last Friday’s announcement. 
Pro-regime news outlet al-Masdar reported that the jets will be used in campaigns on rebel-held Idlib province, which neighbours Aleppo.  
The UK-based monitor the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said that at least 30 air strikes had been carried out in the area in the last few days, despite the current ceasefire deal."
The European part of NATO has no appetite for taking part in the Syrian conflict.  The US (and Canadian) part of NATO is gradually winding down.
This would amount to a declaration of war against Syria without a UN Security Council mandate, which Russia would veto on behalf of their ally.

Incoming Trump administration will attempt to maintain constructive relations with Putin's Russia (and not necessarily keen for anti-Assad/Islamist forces to succeed). No chance of other NATO members adopting no-fly policy, without US backing.
Syria / Russsia / Turkey intend to retake all of Syria.
Affirming forecast. No reason to think this will change.
Airstrikes by Russia Buttress Turkey in Battle vs ISIS
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

The diplomatic and military preconditions for establishing a no-fly zone are absent. NATO has been reluctant to commit to a no-fly zone, despite Turkey's repeated requests to NATO allies to establish one over Northern Syria. The international community also understands that establishing a no-fly zone will require support from the UNSC, which is highly unlikely given Russia's veto power. Trump has indicated that he does not support a no-fly zone. However, even if the Trump administration's security officials wanted to pursue a no-fly zone, Trump's comfortable relationship with Putin makes this policy option unlikely. Further, 1 April 2017 is just over 10 weeks after inauguration, and it is unlikely that any major policy on Syria will be achieved in that short time frame.
No one will have the resources or guts.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

US may provide ground based anti-air weapons to Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) rebels who are fighting ISIS in Syria.  Although ISIS has no aircraft, suggestion is that someday they may need them.  As Syria, Turk and Russian cease fire negotiations begin, the US backed rebels may have a separate agenda.  The anti-air weapons may make a no-fly zone less likely before April 1, 2017,  it still may be the long term objective.

European members of the Alliance (UK, FR, DE) that have significant air and ground assets to enforce a NFZ have other priorities (migrants, terror attacks, elections, etc.) at this time. USA still in leadership transition.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Countries officially involved in the conflict: US, Iran, Iraq, Russia, Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan (7).
they might feel they have to flex their muscles against Russia, but probably not.
Not without the permission of Russia.
Unfortunately too little too late. No country is concerned enough to take this kind of action. Overall feeling 'we give up and we'll see what happens' ...
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
With Trump having shot down the possibility of this in his debates, and his unwillingness to escalate conflict with Russia, and UK busy with the fall-out of Brexit, seems a very low possibility event
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
This is not supported by Russia and PEOTUS Trump will cooperate with Russia in Syria. At least initially.

Establishing an air exclusion zone limits Syria's power to combat insurgents and terrorists. This fact Russia will not allow because it would be a first step to fragment Syria as a step with IRAQ with the exclusion zone of the Kurds.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

https://foreignaffairs.house.gov/press-release/engel-royce-syria-sanctions-bill-passes-house/
opening a window, still unlikely but we will see who becomes Sec of State.

Probably not. The only country which could do it is USA. Trump promised some thing else. Further, USA does not have a legal mandate to declare any thing in Syria. This would mean a high risk of direct confrontation with Russian forces, which is not in the interest of USA. In all regards, the era of being able to declare any no fly zone except over NATO countries, or instigate wars at will is over, and won't come back as soon, if at all. USA wanted it all, and will be left with much less. Even the US population sent the oligarchic establishment for a pause, similar, but for much longer time will happen on the international stage.
never say never, but at this point it is a certain situation that no one else will travel this road. I bet that Turkey will lift the NFZ by spring time.
Not without US leadership, which is unlikely with The Donald as president

With Trump's inauguration, Turkey's threats of massive immigrant outflows to the EU, and Syria closing Aleppo's rebellion- NATO will not do much to initiate any confrontation outside of their own borders.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
i believe President Trump and Putin will come to agreement to enact one either separately or jointly

It's nearly impossible for any NATO member to establish a no fly zone. Most of those nations are busy turning inwards and now governments don't pay as much attention to the Syria issue as they paid earlier. Even US didn't establish a no fly zone, leave alone other countries.
I don't want to go to zero. But unless Trump completely flips on his Syria policy and becomes an Anti-Russian Cold Warrior within 6 weeks after taking office there is no way.

Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan addresses a NATO parliamentary assembly meeting in Istanbul, Monday, Nov. 21, 2016. Erdogan has called on the United States and other nations to re-assess his country's proposal for the creation of a no-fly zone in northern Syria. Addressing the NATO meeting, Erdogan again criticized allies' reliance on Syrian Kurdish fighters to battle the Islamic State group.
After the recent election this probably won't happen.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Don't think there is any political impetus for any nation to do this.
Per last justification but increasing uncertainty.

What if Russia convinces Trump to support a joint no-fly zone over Syria along with Turkey to corral ISIS? Trump's mercurial temperament lends itself to this kind of absurd scenario. And with Bolton or Giuliani as possible secretaries of state, the aggression could be intensified.
is extremely unlikely now Clinton isn't elected president
With President Trump there is nowhere for a move in that direction
Very unlikely based on Trump winning, but whether or not he will be consistent remains. I don't see any other country doing this.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

With Obama on the way out and Trump on the way in, I don't think this is very likely. Trump has repeatedly said that he wants no part in the Syrian civil war, and seems to be more leaning towards diplomatic engagement or stepping back from confronting Putin. That said, Trump is certainly not the most consistent, and he is also apparently considering some very hawkish folks (Sessions, Hadley, and Talent for example) for the Secretary of Defense and Secretary of State (John Bolton), so it could happen. I don't see anyone besides the U.S. doing it however.
I assume that foreign policy-wise there will not be a high change in priorities. To solve the dilemma in Syria a restricted no fly zone will be established in a concerted US-NATO effort.

With the new American administration in place this January, it will be clearer who is in charge of pissing off allies, or the rhetoric of the campaign will dissipate like smoke in a windy summer day. 
It will be interesting to see "if" anyone is next to get the shock therapy of NATO go take a hike rhetoric and act upon it.
The provability of this event, suddenly, has increased!

There's no Nato-member, which is willing, to reinforce such a zone by the risc of losing men for a foreign war, because that's nowadays very unpopular in most NATO-states. And no fly zones allways end in "we bring soldiers in"-zones. Which means: Our men die.
Downgrading this to almost no chance as Trump will not interfere with Russia or Assad
really, this question is about Trump. he has made his position clear. If another country in NATO wants to shoot down Russian planes/enforce a no-fly zone I will be shocked.
With Russian air defense in place, I doubt Turkey will even feel the game worth the candle.
(testing intuition, haven't done any research) Neither Trump nor European leaders seem keen on a no-fly zone. But Trump is a bit of a wild card so he might do it.
at the end of the military offensive in siria, next year, NATO will establish a NFZ to assure the military operation of peace making/establish.
Turkey Syrian Kurds disagree over Raqqa offensive
Assad and Russia would't stand for it - and wouldn't honour it if it occurred
Not going to happen with Obama or Trump. And as the US usually takes the lead on these things ...
Change of administrations makes any quick action unlikely

After tomorrow, Obama will be a lame-duck President and I don't expect his Syria policy to change before he officially leaves office on January 20, 2017. NATO will not move without USA support and Syria is not on either Clinton's or Trump's to-do list in their first 100-days in office, focussing more on their domestic agendas: NBC News, November 5, 'The First 100 Days: Clinton and Trump Offer Their Plans for the Oval Office': http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/2016-election-day/first-100-days-clinton-trump-offer-their-plans-oval-office-n674056

President Clinton has banged on about this so much that she will probably have to declare something over somewhere fairly soon, both for domestic and international consumption.  It will be some part of the country where there is little chance of confronting Russians, and she'll clear it with them on the backchannel beforehand anyway.

Even Guardian notes Hilla's plan for NFZ would cause more problems w Kremlin.  This is the ticket to a "Fail Safe" 2.0  Link https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/25/hillary-clinton-syria-no-fly-zones-russia-us-war

It is pure fantasy to suggest that ANYONE will  establish a  NFZ over Syria  

Russia will block any UN Security Council moves in this direction

We are told that Clinton may be more 'hawkish' in foreign policy in the future - but really, this is just posturing.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

A Clinton presidency, arguably less patient or accommodating with Russian interests, especially represented by a Putin government, than any U.S. president of recent memory. This, in combination with prolonged UN Security Council impasse, NATO's frustration with the stalemate and its humanitarian cost, the European Union's incapacity to handle the resulting refugees flow, and Turkey's military harassment of U.S.-backed Kurdish fighters, could lead to see a no-fly zone as a politically palatable and operationally desirable solution.
U S News Website (2016) reports “Game Changer”:

A no-fly zone can only be directed against Assad and the Russians (they are the ones with the planes). NATO won't risk a confrontation with Russia over that, and neither would any US president (at least not before trying to negotiate).

Clinton has said it should be done. Trump has not. Obama has not done it yet. It does not seem likely that Obama would do it in his last few weeks. With the size of the Russian presence in and around Syria a no-fly zone without the agreement of Russia would be very risky. At the moment I don't see Russia agreeing. I assume any no-fly zone would be to protect civilians in areas where not much fighting is taking place. Turkey has been interested in the area along its border with Syria. The West has been most concerned about the bombing in Aleppo, but by late January it could be too late to help with a no-fly zone there. The US public would not want to create a no-fly zone over IS territory. Russia would resist one being set up in north-west Syria. So the only likely areas would be over territory controlled by Turkey (which Turkey could do itself) or over territory controlled by the Kurds, which could set Turkey and the US at odds. So I think it unlikely to happen.

The game is different, ow we are far from announcing anything, even if in facts it might be similar.  There might be a Russian influence, but unsaid, they won't risk to "loose face" over such a thing. But trade it in, yes.
US will do so under a Clinton Administration

I think it would be unlikely that Trump would impose a no-fly zone and even Hillary would probably found it hard to implement, since Russian would likely not agree to it. If Russian doesn't agree to it it would be dangerous and ill advised to set that red line, even with NATO nation support.
The current framework and ground dynamics do not accommodate the declaration of a no fly zone in the given period.
There's a possibility the Hillary is going to start her foreign policy off with guns blazing. The Russian's did, after all, try to prevent her from being elected.
We had a chance to do this, I argued for it, I lost points when we failed, now Syria a worse mess, Erdogan opportunity completely gone and Ryssia strengthend. Ouch.

In order for this to happen one of two things must occur. The US and Russia agree to a no fly zone or the US and NATO decide to impose one without Russian support and risk the consequences of an armed incident, accidental or not, with Russian forces.

If SYrians take Aleppo, and Kurds continue to control areas further east, and Syria and Russia do not object to strenuously, perhaps Clinton would make populist move of declaring a no fly zone over some Kurdish/refugee protection areas.  
A shhort time frame makes this less likely as Syria / Russia must cooperate on a longer term strategy, and the new president needs to bring a new commitment to reinforce the partition of Syria during the first 70 days of a new admin.
Cannot imagine a situation where Russia, Assad & Iran would agree to one...
It is not in the best interest of other nations to take such an action.
US: Russia ships new anti-missile system into Syria
It simply would make no sense to stake national prestige on declaring a no fly zone. That doesn't mean a missile enforced or other de-factor one won't emerge though.
OK, now that the date is correct, my forecast is officially zero.
The only one who might do this is Clinton, who has said she thinks it wise.  However, she won't get around to before April, if ever.  Everybody else is a Very Dark Horse in this race.

I assume this question will be voided and republished with the correct date. Assuming that happens, I will still forecast zero possibility. Obama won't impose one, Trump won't, and Clinton will be unable to; no one wants to risk a confrontation with Russia over this, and Clinton will not have the political capital to change anyone's mind, assuming she gets elected. No European power has the ability to impose one, so that settles that.

Going a bit lower on second thought. 
Also, @rjfmgy makes a valid point about the timeframe of the question.;)
(Closing date is accurate though)

If it would be possible to get Russia to tolerate this (if not endorse), this could be a good & long overdue step to save civilian lifes. However, I cannot see why Russia should be motivated to agree to this at the moment & why any NATO member should step forward in this timeframe. Any ideas?
Clinton might be President and be inclined to do this.
As it appears now, no way soon, if ever. Will have to keep an eye on the Soviet expansionist intervention in the region and support of Assad.ðŸ¤”
In the absence of the ability to make time move backward, I would say to ask this question is to answer it.
